A great concept for a multiplayer naval combat game, with some significant caveats.  

If you are primarily interested in player vs. player matches (random and ranked battles) you should know that you are at a disadvantage playing the free "tech-tree" ships vs. the "premium" ships that are primarily acquired directly or indirectly by paying money.  A play-for-free player can definitely acquire some of these premium ships, but overwhelmingly a pay-to-play player will have a far deeper and robust bench of ships to employ.

Nonetheless, there is a great deal of cooperative play content (co-op matches, operations, asymmetrical battles) and if these appeal to you then you can find a very fun and rewarding game.  You play against AI bots and while you may have teammates with overpowered ships, you do not feel at a disadvantage winning vs. losing.

Lastly, this game is very suitable for teaming up with your friends.  Matches of any type with friends is a great deal of fun.

The gameplay is built not only around shooting but also around tactics. Positioning, concealment, engagement distance, and understanding the strengths of each ship class make every match intense and engaging. It‚Äôs especially nice that different ships feel distinct: destroyers are fast and stealthy, cruisers are versatile, battleships are powerful but slow, and aircraft carriers require strategic thinking.

The progression system motivates you to keep playing, unlock new tech-tree lines, and upgrade your ships. Regular events, modes, and updates keep the game fresh. Team battles often deliver those memorable moments when victory depends on a single well-placed salvo or a smart maneuver.

Yes, matchmaking and balance can sometimes be frustrating, but overall the game remains fair and exciting ‚Äî especially if you love history or naval battles.

Having played and still actively playing Wows since 2015; I can say in confidence I think it is a good game. I was recently able to convert my main WG account over to Steam, which easily has a couple thousand hours. Since learning of the game all the way back in 2015 from one of BaronVonGames' videos, the ability to visualize historic and non historic ships, and machines of war was the biggest pull for me to start playing. 

The game has a relatively low skill ceiling, of which increases at a good pace as you progress. Continuous updates, additions, and events, make the game fun to play even if you cannot play that frequently. 

I will say though, similar to many modern MMO's, Wows' only hamartia is its FOMO mechanics and cash grabs. Although you will progress through the game quicker than other games such as Warthunder, many added premium items or new ships are sold for obscene prices, or are to be gambled for; to then in some cases be nerfed to the floor. 

Moreover, gameplay is extremely fun especially when you do get the hang of things, figure out lead times, how to angle, and general map knowledge. Yet newer additions see newer gimmicks and mechanics that do take away from the fun and lean the game more towards stupidity, rather than actual logic. This increases exponentially as you play higher tiers VIII-X. For example additions like Valparaiso, high tier subs, high tier CVs, and of course airstrikes. However, the biggest issue you will face like any other multiplayer game is; your teammates.

Gameplay is entertaining, but not when you have your entire team leave the flank to go sit behind one island or in the corner of the map. Also not fun when you have no DD or CV to spot. So teammates are a big part of the game, and if you have friends to play with even better, as it will save you headaches. 

For a free game, I would easily pay for it if told otherwise.

I've had a lot of fun with this game and have not seen anything else that can offer a good similar experience, but I do struggle somewhat to recommend it due to some economic design decisions.

Gameplay-wise, this game has a lot going for it with a variety of pvp and pve game modes.

Starting with pvp, which seems to be the focus of development, there are four "standard" game modes: random matches, ranked matches, brawls, and clan battles. Random matches are the most basic form, with large teams of mostly-unrelated players competing to destroy the other team, capture specific locations, or otherwise win by out-scoring the opposing team. These are generally uncoordinated and vary significantly in quality from match to match. ranked matches are similar, but with smaller teams and a tighter selection of ships available. This allows greater individual impact and generally has better communication, but in my experience also has a more toxic playerbase. Brawls are the most extreme extension of this, allowing ships of only a single tier and limited classes with teams of three or fewer ships each on smaller maps. These are usually quick matches with varying levels of strategy (usually not too much) an team coordination (its easy to support your team but unreliable to expect them to support you). Clan battles take random match team sizes, but compose teams of players within the same clan for potentially much better teamwork and more complex strategy, but I haven't played this mode, so I can't say how it turns out in practice. Brawls are my favorite of the pvp modes, where I mostly play utility cruisers.

Moving on to pve, there are two main game modes: co-op and operations. Co-op is the first mode available to teach players the game, an involves simple bots that functionally act as a shooting gallery for players who want an easy time sailing around in their virtual boats. It also has a guaranteed quick wait time, capped at 30 seconds. Operations is only available for tiers six and up, and adds (slightly) smarter bots and missions with specific objectives and sub objectives for a relatively small team of players. this is my favorite game mode, but it is definitely limited by a somewhat small selection of mission scenarios. Some of the scenarios have randomization in the order or location of bot/objective spawns, but they are still fairly easy to learn after a few matches of each scenario/spawn combo. Additionally, asymmetric matches are sometimes available, and play like co-op with much smarter bots and a small, higher-tier team of players opposing a large, lower-tier team of bots.


Shifting over to economic aspects, the game consists of both free-to-play and paid content, but I have not found it to be particularly pay-to-win.

When playing the free content, the game is fairly grind-centric in the long-term, but if you find a line of ships you enjoy playing individual matches in, said grind can be fun despite the time sink required to ultimately complete the line. So be prepared to take your time working through the game, and take care to enjoy the ride rather than simply rushing to the end. 

When considering spending money on the game, remember that everything is overpriced, some things quite dramatically so. As such it is important to first determine what your goal is in doing so. If you want a specific ship, try to use coupons, and know that it is always better to just buy that ship than to rely on any of the gambling mechanics. In contrast, if you just want to maximize the number of sips you have or can get, save for events that have good drop chances (I believe Christmas, Anniversary, or Black Friday events are generally the best in this regard). If you are looking for the best deal for progression in the game, I recommend getting premium time deals near the holiday/new year season when there is a deal. Depending on how much time you have to play, 3-6 months can last forever supported by additional time gained from events, or a year can provide a stronger buffer with less playtime to maintain it.

Ultimately, I am recommending the game because I have enjoyed free content, and think that there is a lot to get out of it if you have the time and are looking for the gameplay provided.

At the moment, I do not recommend the game.
I would only recommend it if you genuinely enjoy naval combat, ships, and the WWII aesthetic and you have no intention of falling into the gacha loop or the pressure of ‚Äúplaying to win.‚Äù
If your goal is simply to enjoy the battles, take the game lightly, and play free-to-play because you like the ships or the era, then yes ‚Äî you can still have fun.
I‚Äôve been a player for over eight years, even before the Steam release, and I‚Äôve witnessed many stages of the game: its evolution‚Ä¶ and its degeneration.

‚û§ The main issue: the gacha model

A few years ago, the game introduced a business model based on loot boxes, random rolls, and probability systems.
This completely changed the experience:

It‚Äôs no longer just paying for a ship.
Now it introduces anxiety, bundles, odds, and the illusion of obtaining something valuable.
Ships have become excuses to generate spending, more than actual content.

While there is some generosity toward free-to-play players, that generosity is completely tied to profit.
They cannot be ‚Äútoo generous‚Äù unless revenue stays high ‚Äî and it shows.

‚û§ The rarity system reinforces the gacha feeling

The game also added a rarity-based ship classification system, depending on how frequently ships appear or how difficult they are to obtain. The categories go from Common to Legendary:

Common (gray): standard tech-tree ships
Uncommon (green): often premium or shop ships
Rare (blue): usually Research Bureau ships or ships obtained with coal or steel
Epic (orange): time-limited ships; very difficult or expensive to obtain
Legendary (yellow): extremely rare; I own none, and the Captain‚Äôs Logbook only shows two legendary ships in total

This system shifts the focus from gameplay to collection pressure, encouraging investment based on scarcity more than value.

‚û§ Game balance: certain ships dominate ranked

The variety of ships and playstyles has always been one of the game‚Äôs strongest points.
However, lately I‚Äôve noticed bad players performing well simply because the ships they use are overly strong, especially:

Pan-American battleships
German alternate cruisers

In Random Battles, the balance is still somewhat acceptable due to larger team sizes (12 vs 12).
But in Ranked Battles, any ship from these lines heavily tilts the match, and if a skilled player is behind them, the difference becomes overwhelming.

‚û§ The deeper issue: the psychology of PvP

In any PvP game, players ultimately want to win.
So when a ship becomes S-tier ‚Äî whether premium, special, epic, or part of a tech tree ‚Äî many players choose it simply because it increases their chances of victory.

But when everyone gravitates toward the same S-tier ships, the game stops being about skill and becomes a race to pick the strongest tool.
This creates a meta where diversity disappears and the experience becomes unbalanced and predictable.

The dangerous part is that players often don‚Äôt even realize this is happening.
They think they are ‚Äújust playing to win,‚Äù while the entire environment is being shaped around a handful of overtuned ships that distort the whole match experience.

And the developers likely understand this dynamic.
If an overpowered ship generates revenue, the cycle repeats:

A new strong ship appears
Players rush to get it
The meta breaks
The next strong ship is released
The loop continues
This self-reinforcing cycle benefits monetization at the expense of balance.

There are also other game modes that can be enjoyable for casual play, farming missions, or playing with friends, such as Operations and the occasional Asymmetric Battles. These modes still offer some fun and variety outside the main gameplay loop.

‚û§ Naval variety: its biggest strength‚Ä¶ with a big ‚Äúbut‚Äù

The game includes real historical ships, prototypes, and ships that never existed.
Each nation has its own mechanics and identity, and some hybrid concepts are genuinely interesting.

But one thing ruins part of the experience:
it doesn‚Äôt feel good to play a real historical ship and get destroyed by a design that never existed, especially when that fictional ship is clearly superior for commercial reasons.

Yes, many ships are free-to-play friendly and obtainable with steel or coal ‚Äî and that remains one of the best aspects of the game.
But even this gets overshadowed by the greed behind bundles and the gacha system.

‚û§ Gameplay mechanics that no longer maintain even the illusion of realism

The game was never fully realistic, but it used to maintain a coherent naval atmosphere.
That illusion breaks when mechanics such as these appear:

Cruisers and destroyers launching bomber planes
Abilities that contradict traditional naval logic

These mechanics completely break immersion.

‚û§ FOMO and psychological pressure

Many events and limited ships rely heavily on FOMO (fear of missing out).
This encourages quick purchases, impulsive decisions, and the constant feeling that you‚Äôre always ‚Äúmissing‚Äù something important.
Ship collectors are especially vulnerable.

For this reason, I do not recommend spending money on a game that relies more on illusions and psychological pressure than genuine value.

‚û§ In the end, what matters is not what the game offers, but what you expect from it.
The experience depends less on the game and more on what you seek inside it.

Are you playing the game‚Ä¶ or is the game playing you?

What initially drew me to try this game was the collaboration with with Azur Lane, a different free to play historical ship game. Destroyers are basically the only real killers in this game. Fire off torpedoes in the enemies general direcion, and 1 to 2 min later you will be notified that something died. I have been a fan of World of Warships for ten years. It is a true gem, telling the story of naval fleets and warships, allowing players to dream and admire the art and engineering of these incredible vessels. Since childhood, I have been fascinated by the navy, and for me, World of Warships was a true discovery ‚Äî a whole new world where I got lost for many years. I loved studying ships and their history, and when the game first appeared, I registered almost from its very birth. Immersing myself in this world of history and adventure was magical.

Over time, however, the game began to decline ‚Äî slowly but steadily. This became especially noticeable after the complete move to the European server. Numerous inconveniences appeared. For example, in certain battle types ‚Äî cooperative and asymmetric ‚Äî players using destroyers and cruisers often have an advantage, while others face difficulties. The balance is disrupted, and instead of simply enjoying naval battles, players are forced to select specific ships and use special mechanics just to keep up. This partially applies to random battles as well.

Problems also appeared with the Support Center. There were inconsistencies in information about gift and loot boxes ‚Äî for example, regarding the chances of receiving ships or valuable items. The developers partially addressed this by showing how many boxes are needed before a guaranteed ship drop. Yet the inconveniences remain. Previously, responses to inquiries came almost the same day; now it can take weeks. And even when a reply arrives, it is often purely formal ‚Äî it does not reveal the essence of the issue, does not take the specific situation into account, and does not lead to a solution. Many issues remain unchanged.

As a lover of history ‚Äî especially the history of the German navy ‚Äî I owned almost all German ships available in the game. Many of them I purchased with real money to complete my collection. In addition, I bought many other ships ‚Äî those I liked, that had historical significance, or that were designed with care and imagination. And now, though it pains me, I realize it is time to free myself from this pleasant addiction and part with all of it.

Today, the game no longer considers the interests of veteran players who have supported it for years. It has lost its customer-oriented nature. World of Warships calls itself free-to-play, but the pressure to spend is growing ‚Äî and the costs are higher. Even my long-term premium subscription now offers far fewer benefits than before.

All these factors have led me to one conclusion: after ten years, I understand that the game has run its course. I would like to say ‚Äúthank you,‚Äù but, alas, I cannot. Those who do not change ‚Äî who stop listening and evolving ‚Äî are destined to fade into oblivion.

Yet I remain sincerely grateful to the people ‚Äî the original team ‚Äî who created this game. My deepest gratitude and respect to everyone who gave life to this project. World of Warships is a remarkable and beautiful creation for true admirers of naval history and the fleet.
But to the current management, I must say: you are not professionals, and your actions are destroying the soul of this game.

It is time to free myself from this pleasant addiction. Farewell.

Playing on higher tiers is a financial trap. Instead of enjoying the ships you‚Äôve been grinding for years, the system punishes you with massive maintenance costs. Even when you‚Äôre using a premium ship, one bad match and you end up in the red. Yes, you literally pay for the privilege of playing. That‚Äôs not motivation ‚Äì that‚Äôs discouragement.

Premium ships are not premium. They are supposed to make credits and be a reward for your investment, but the reality is that even with a ship you bought for real money, you can easily finish a game with minus 200k credits just because you got sunk early. That‚Äôs a joke.

The entire system is designed to force you to spend. Without a premium account, boosters, or permanent camo, playing on higher tiers is practically unsustainable. The game pushes you to either pay or grind endlessly on lower tiers just to afford a few games at T9‚ÄìT10-*

WG exploits players. Instead of rewarding time and skill, they tuned the economy so that even after a decent performance you often don‚Äôt earn as much as you should. This is intentional, not a mistake. And you can feel it in every battle.

I played this game for quite a while.

I liked it a lot, but as time went on, Wargaming seemed keen on scraping the bottom of the barrel labeled "Box O' Gimmicks".

And trust me, I was fairly resilient to the constant change the game's meta had. I thought Aircraft carriers were OK, just needed some work. Submarines... were implemented terribly, with an insane degree of arcade-y feel to them.

But everyone has something that was "The Last Straw" when it comes to leaving this game.

For me, that was Superships, AKA Tier 11.

Understand that world of warships has a degree of arcade feel and historical source material, that is attempted to be balanced on a razor's edge, an edge that got finer as time went on. I feel the arcade feel is warranted, as otherwise we would have the snooze fest that is War Thunder's Naval mode (not to mention bigger = better). However, as Wargaming proceeds to scrape the Box O' Gimmicks barrel, the scale of arcade vs historical "feeling" tips too far to arcade-y.

That is what superships introduced. Ultimately for me, it was Burst Fire that broke it for me. How the hell does a fictional late 40s, early 50's paper ship design magically fire salvo after salvo, with a second interval between them? The answer? They can't! Only modern systems can achieve that, not designs rooted in late 40's, early 50's.

This is what shattered the fun for me. Which leads to the next point: Economy.

I spent so much time grinding for tier IX and X ships. And then they add superships so bored veterans with a bottomless supply of credits can just play a overpowered ship that has the infamous F-Key or colloquially known as "The Funny Button". Be it the impossible burst fire mechanic or "I have magic dispersion on THIS salvo, you are guaranteed to DIE". So I grind my tier IX ship, that faces these dumb superships and just get dumpstered if it's not a meta ship for tier IX. This was before the gap between tier IX and X wasn't so large.

The economy in general is just garbage. You HAVE to have premium time if you want to grind in any meaningful amount of time, and it's not just for XP, it's for credits! If I wanted to buy all my tier IX and X ships, I would legit need like multi-million amount of credits to do so. This is another reason I stopped playing because I was getting so tired of just playing Kii that had a special camo (now eco-bonus) that gave extra credits, making it one of the most efficient credit farmers beyond any lucky person that has Missouri before it went off sale. It gets real boring when I have to essentially play the same ship for probably 200 battles to get ~200 million odd credits I need to get all my tier IX & ships BEFORE upgrades.

I had to stop myself from buying credits outright because I was getting so tired of grinding credits, and once I dropped cold hard cash just for credits, I asked myself, "What the hell am I doing spending 100$ for the ability to buy like maybe 3 top tier ships??" There are other monetary problems with this game, such as FOMO tactics, delayed releases of ships outside bundles (seriously, when was the last time they released a new premium that WASN'T first part of a bundle?!), and how some ships are just not available anymore, and can only be gambled for in santa crate boxes.

This game has a great amount of love put into in some areas, be it the ship models, the Original Game Soundtrack (Artur Tokhtash is the GOAT!!), and so on. I really liked dockyard modes, it felt meaningful to grind and complete missions to get new pieces to your ship. The gameplay loop is solid... when steamrolls don't occur. The classes interact with eachother mostly in a balanced manner.

There was a lot to love, but this game has just gotten worse and worse, more and more arcade-y, all in the endless pursuit to scrap more gunk out of the bottom of the barrel labeled "Box O' Gimmicks".

Maybe one day Wargaming can do something to course correct, but as it stands, I cannot bear playing this game anymore.

At the moment, I do not recommend the game.
I would only recommend it if you genuinely enjoy naval combat, ships, and the WWII aesthetic and you have no intention of falling into the gacha loop or the pressure of ‚Äúplaying to win.‚Äù
If your goal is simply to enjoy the battles, take the game lightly, and play free-to-play because you like the ships or the era, then yes ‚Äî you can still have fun.
I‚Äôve been a player for over eight years, even before the Steam release, and I‚Äôve witnessed many stages of the game: its evolution‚Ä¶ and its degeneration.

‚û§ The main issue: the gacha model

A few years ago, the game introduced a business model based on loot boxes, random rolls, and probability systems.
This completely changed the experience:

It‚Äôs no longer just paying for a ship.
Now it introduces anxiety, bundles, odds, and the illusion of obtaining something valuable.
Ships have become excuses to generate spending, more than actual content.

While there is some generosity toward free-to-play players, that generosity is completely tied to profit.
They cannot be ‚Äútoo generous‚Äù unless revenue stays high ‚Äî and it shows.

‚û§ The rarity system reinforces the gacha feeling

The game also added a rarity-based ship classification system, depending on how frequently ships appear or how difficult they are to obtain. The categories go from Common to Legendary:

Common (gray): standard tech-tree ships
Uncommon (green): often premium or shop ships
Rare (blue): usually Research Bureau ships or ships obtained with coal or steel
Epic (orange): time-limited ships; very difficult or expensive to obtain
Legendary (yellow): extremely rare; I own none, and the Captain‚Äôs Logbook only shows two legendary ships in total

This system shifts the focus from gameplay to collection pressure, encouraging investment based on scarcity more than value.

‚û§ Game balance: certain ships dominate ranked

The variety of ships and playstyles has always been one of the game‚Äôs strongest points.
However, lately I‚Äôve noticed bad players performing well simply because the ships they use are overly strong, especially:

Pan-American battleships
German alternate cruisers

In Random Battles, the balance is still somewhat acceptable due to larger team sizes (12 vs 12).
But in Ranked Battles, any ship from these lines heavily tilts the match, and if a skilled player is behind them, the difference becomes overwhelming.

‚û§ The deeper issue: the psychology of PvP

In any PvP game, players ultimately want to win.
So when a ship becomes S-tier ‚Äî whether premium, special, epic, or part of a tech tree ‚Äî many players choose it simply because it increases their chances of victory.

But when everyone gravitates toward the same S-tier ships, the game stops being about skill and becomes a race to pick the strongest tool.
This creates a meta where diversity disappears and the experience becomes unbalanced and predictable.

The dangerous part is that players often don‚Äôt even realize this is happening.
They think they are ‚Äújust playing to win,‚Äù while the entire environment is being shaped around a handful of overtuned ships that distort the whole match experience.

And the developers likely understand this dynamic.
If an overpowered ship generates revenue, the cycle repeats:

A new strong ship appears
Players rush to get it
The meta breaks
The next strong ship is released
The loop continues
This self-reinforcing cycle benefits monetization at the expense of balance.

There are also other game modes that can be enjoyable for casual play, farming missions, or playing with friends, such as Operations and the occasional Asymmetric Battles. These modes still offer some fun and variety outside the main gameplay loop.

‚û§ Naval variety: its biggest strength‚Ä¶ with a big ‚Äúbut‚Äù

The game includes real historical ships, prototypes, and ships that never existed.
Each nation has its own mechanics and identity, and some hybrid concepts are genuinely interesting.

But one thing ruins part of the experience:
it doesn‚Äôt feel good to play a real historical ship and get destroyed by a design that never existed, especially when that fictional ship is clearly superior for commercial reasons.

Yes, many ships are free-to-play friendly and obtainable with steel or coal ‚Äî and that remains one of the best aspects of the game.
But even this gets overshadowed by the greed behind bundles and the gacha system.

‚û§ Gameplay mechanics that no longer maintain even the illusion of realism

The game was never fully realistic, but it used to maintain a coherent naval atmosphere.
That illusion breaks when mechanics such as these appear:

Cruisers and destroyers launching bomber planes
Abilities that contradict traditional naval logic

These mechanics completely break immersion.

‚û§ FOMO and psychological pressure

Many events and limited ships rely heavily on FOMO (fear of missing out).
This encourages quick purchases, impulsive decisions, and the constant feeling that you‚Äôre always ‚Äúmissing‚Äù something important.
Ship collectors are especially vulnerable.

For this reason, I do not recommend spending money on a game that relies more on illusions and psychological pressure than genuine value.

‚û§ In the end, what matters is not what the game offers, but what you expect from it.
The experience depends less on the game and more on what you seek inside it.
